title: What does the bible say about adultery? - Quora

response.answer_text: I suppose you know that adultery is sexual infidelity to the marriage relationship, soi guess you’re really asking one of the following questions. What actions rise to the level of sexual infidelity? How serious of a sin is adultery? The Bible initially sets the standard of sexual infidelity at physical sexual congress, commonly expressed as “knowing” or “lie together” (nice euphemisms to clear everything up). The reliance on euphemisms indicates that it can be a sin just to think too hard about the subject…ooops, but in the Old Testament this isn’t regarded as the same as adultery. Jesus sets another line for “committing adultery in your heart”. It should be noted that “committing adultery in your heart” is probably about as similar to actual adultery as “saying a silent thank you” is to actually paying for something. However, it is certainly clear that being thankful for goods received is a usual precursor to honestly paying for them, and so to it is doubtful whether adultery often occurs physically before it occurs in the heart. “Thou shalt be grateful for every good thing thou receivest” is a great precursor to keeping “thou shalt not steal”…but it is not the exact same commandment. So, I’m going to say that adultery is actual sexual contact with another actual person. But it is clear that one can sin well short of this extreme. For instance, a person seeking a degree of sexual titillation or emotional satisfaction outside of marriage may not be committing “put away for the cause of” adultery, but still be in serious need of repentance. So how serious a sin is adultery? It’s basically “you just ruined someone’s life” serious. The Old Testament sanctions killing over it…but the Old Testament sanctions killing over picking your nose on the wrong day (or something like that). But even Jesus is okay with casting a wife aside and thus denying her financial and social support and legal recognition as a human being. Ouch. I suppose there’s supposed to be some penalty for adulterous men…is it still just the killing? Jesus doesn’t really say. So I guess the Old Testament is where it’s at for the men. Okay, but like I said, Old Testament lethal sanctions don’t really scale well. So let’s think about this logically. What happens when you have sex outside of marriage? Well, you have kids outside of marriage, and they grow up without the appropriate relationship with both parents (and not just “not both”, the relationship of a child to a single parent is really difficult for both, maybe better than no relationship at all with the other parent, but well below the relationship with a married parent). And it ruins lives. We know this, the science is very clear. When you commit adultery, it’s basically like drinking and driving. It’s not a “victimless crime”, it just takes a while doing it before you actually see the blood in the streets. Yeah, people can live happy and fulfilling lives after you cripple them in a car ‘accident’ you caused for the sake of your own pleasure. That doesn’t make it an okay thing to do. And not everyone goes on to live a happy, fulfilling life. Some do, some don’t. Put it this way. Committing adultery in your heart is like getting wasted watching football on TV and sleeping it off on the couch. Not a great thing for your life, probably something you should think about changing, but hardly a terrible crime. Committing physical adultery is like getting wasted at a bar before driving home…every weekend. Sooner or later you’re going to ruin somebody’s life for real. You might think you’re being smart about it and nobody will get hurt…you might even die before those odds catch up with you. You still played dice with someone’s life. That’s not a good thing.

Actually, it’s hard to say. It violates one of the Ten Commandments, but whether that counts as a sin is debatable. An argument can be made for Jesus breaking perhaps four or five of the Ten Commandments, and He was said to be without sin. He breaks the Fourth Commandment by permitting His disciples to work on the Sabbath by gathering crops, excusing that infraction by claiming that the Sabbath was made for man, and not man made for the Sabbath, turning the commandment upside down. He breaks the Fifth Commandment by back-talking His mother during the wedding feast at Cana, when she asked Him to turn wine into water, He replied “Woman, what have I to do with thee?” If I spoke to my mother with that kind of sass, she’d whup me upside the head. He breaks the Eighth Commandment by instructing His disciples to take possession of two animals on which He would ride into Jerusalem during the week before Passover, on Palm Sunday, stealing them if necessary. He breaks the Ninth Commandment by telling His disciples He won’t be attending the Feast of the Tabernacles, but goes there in secret and with great dramatic effect He reveals Himself and begins preaching. Jesus tells a parable about a beggar, Lazarus, who broke the Tenth Commandment by coveting the table scraps from a rich man’s table; shortly after that in the story, the beggar dies and ends up in heaven. So, that doesn’t seem to be any kind of sin that was punished. Further, Jesus absolves a harlot woman who was found guilty of breaking the Seventh Commandment by committing adultery, and grants her clemency from the punishment mandated by God Himself in the Old Testament. If the Apocrypha is to be believed, specifically the Infancy Gospel of Thomas, Jesus broke the Sixth Commandment by killing two of His playmates as a young child. So, whether breaking any of the Ten Commandments is a sin is up for discussion - it doesn’t seem to be a sin when Jesus does it.
